title: Penalty cut a win for business but it is 'WorkChoices-dangerous' for Malcolm Turnbull
text:
Minister: Power surplus, but please don't ... Minister: Power surplus, but please don't use it. 
NSW Energy and Utilities Minister Don Harwin has requested the public make restrictions to their power usage between peak times to prevent potential rolling blackouts, despite claiming we have a power surplus. More videos Penalty rates: leaders allocate blame 
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten and Minister for Employment Michaelia Cash trade barbs on who is responsible for the penalty rate change announced Thursday. (Vision courtesy ABC News 24) 
The decision is a victory for capital's tactical demand for incremental reductions. 
Even so, the micro-economic benefits remain contested, the individual effect of the cuts harsh, and the politics therefore, dangerous. How much? For Malcolm Turnbull, think WorkChoices-dangerous. Related Content It's what they wanted, but it hurts 
Hospitality and retail outlets currently not trading seven days due to labour costs could well open on Sundays as a result of this decision. But let's say they do. How much of their new trade will come from other cafes and shops? 
Even among new weekend consumers, some will have merely switched their purchasing from a weekday to a weekend. Advertisement 
For the workers currently employed on Sundays however, this inherently "retrospective" decision could be severe. The ACTU predicts individual losses up to $6000 annually. 
Lower-paid workers tend to spend everything they earn. Pay cuts for these workers will come straight off demand in other businesses. SHARE
